title: Estimating ancestry proportions
code: library(gauss) library(dplyr) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: afmix() function requires four arguments: Path allele frequency data file. Path reference panel index file (.e., reference_index_file). Path reference data file (.e., reference_data_file). Path reference population description file (.e., reference_pop_desc_file). allele frequency data file include six columns following column names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), af1 (reference allele frequency). Firstly, assign path input file containing rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2 af1. Next, assign paths reference data files variables
code: # Path to the input file input_file <- "/Users/leed13/Desktop/GAUSS/GWAS_data/PGC/PGC2/PGC2_final/ilmn1M/pgc2.chr22.ilmn1M.Af1only.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and af1) input.data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input.data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2       af1 #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G 0.1159800 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C 0.1240050 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G 0.2660650 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G 0.6319500 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C 0.9570250 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G 0.0667805 # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file<-"/path/to/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "/path/to/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"path/to/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: Lastly, execute afmix() function compute ethnic mixing proportions display results neat table.
code: wgt.df <- afmix(input_file=input_file,                 reference_index_file = reference_index_file,                 reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                 reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file)

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
code: wgt.df %>% kable("html")

title: Estimating ancestry proportions
text: , obtain total proportion super population display results table.
code: wgt.df %>%   group_by(sup.pop) %>%   summarise(wgt=sum(wgt), .groups="drop") %>%   kable("html")

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: Linkage disequilibrium (LD) quantifies degree non-random association alleles different loci within population. estimation LD multi-ethnic cohorts, however, can challenging due underlying population structure. computeLD() function GAUSS package addresses challenge offering efficient accurate method estimate LD, factoring mixed ancestries present cohort. vignette provide step--step guide using computeLD() estimating LD SNPs within multi-ethnic Schizophrenia GWAS cohort.

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(reshape2) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: computeLD() function GAUSS package designed estimate Linkage Disequilibrium (LD) leveraging observed estimated ancestry proportions target cohort. calculates LD specific genomic regions weighted sum LD values across various ancestries. LD values ancestry estimated reference panel. example, utilize 33KG reference panel estimations. function requires following arguments: chr: Chromosome number. start_bp: Starting base pair position estimation window. end_bp: Ending base pair position estimation window. pop_wgt_df: R data frame containing population IDs wights input_file: File name association Z-score data reference_index_file: File name reference panel index data reference_data_file: File name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: File name reference panel population description data af1_cutff: Cutoff reference allele (a1) frequency computeLD() function returns list two elements: snplist: data frame containing information SNPs used LD estimation. cormat: matrix LD estimates pair SNPs.

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: ancestry proportion data pop_wgt_df include two columns following names: pop (population abbreviation) wgt (weight proportion). information estimated using afmix() function described . , load ancestry proportion data generated vignette afmix() function:
code: # Load the ancestry proportion data data("PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop") # data frame name: PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop head(PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop) #>   pop   wgt #> 1 ACB 0.006 #> 2 ASW 0.036 #> 3 BEB 0.005 #> 4 CCE 0.008 #> 5 CCS 0.004 #> 6 CDX 0.018

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: association Z-score data file space-delimited text file including six columns following names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), z (association Z-score). assign path association Z-score data file :
code: # Define the path to the input file input_file <- "/Users/leed13/Desktop/GAUSS/GWAS_data/PGC/PGC2/PGC2_final/ilmn1M/pgc2.chr22.ilmn1M.Zonly.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input_data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input_data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2          z #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G -1.4969741 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C  1.8407377 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G  2.1683772 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G -0.0556759 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C  2.9694844 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G -0.8957244

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: Next, assign paths reference panel data files:
code: # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file<-"/path/to/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "/path/to/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"path/to/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: necessary arguments data prepared, can now estimate Linkage Disequilibrium specific genomic region using computeLD() function. example, focus 1Mb genomic region located Chr 22: 26M-27M.
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- computeLD(chr=22, start_bp = 26000001, end_bp = 27000000,                  pop_wgt_df = PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop,                  input_file = input_file,                   reference_index_file = reference_index_file,                  reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                   reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,                  af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)

title: Estimating Linkage Disequilibrium within a multi-ethnic cohort
text: Letâ€™s display first entries results: Finally, generate heatmap visually represent LD estimates:
code: head(res$snplist) %>% kable("html") head(res$cormat[1:3,1:3]) #>              [,1]          [,2]          [,3] #> [1,]  1.000000000 -0.0075102182 -0.0461570012 #> [2,] -0.007510218  1.0000000000 -0.0007550191 #> [3,] -0.046157001 -0.0007550191  1.0000000000 cormat <- res$cormat diag(cormat) <- NA cormelt <- melt(cormat, na.rm = TRUE) #> Warning in melt(cormat, na.rm = TRUE): The melt generic in data.table has #> been passed a matrix and will attempt to redirect to the relevant reshape2 #> method; please note that reshape2 is deprecated, and this redirection is now #> deprecated as well. To continue using melt methods from reshape2 while both #> libraries are attached, e.g. melt.list, you can prepend the namespace like #> reshape2::melt(cormat). In the next version, this warning will become an error.  ggplot(data = cormelt, aes(x = Var1, y = Var2, fill = value)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_gradient2(low = "blue", high = "red",                         mid = "white",                         midpoint = 0, limit = c(-1,1),                         space = "Lab") +   scale_y_reverse() +   theme_minimal() +    theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(),         axis.text.y = element_blank(),         axis.ticks = element_blank(),         axis.title.x = element_blank(),         axis.title.y = element_blank(),         panel.grid.major = element_blank(),         panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),         legend.position = "none") +   coord_fixed()

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: dist() function requires ten arguments: 1. chr chromosome number 2. start_bp start base pair position prediction window 3. end_bp end base pair position prediction window 4. wing_size size area flanking left right prediction window 5. study_pop study population group 6. input_file Path association Z-score data file. 7. reference_index_file Path reference panel index file (.e., reference_index_file). 8. reference_data_file Path reference data file (.e., reference_data_file). 9. reference_pop_desc_file Path reference population description file (.e., reference_pop_desc_file). 10. af1_cutoff cutoff reference allele, a1, frequency association Z-score data file include six columns following column names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), z (association Z-score). Firstly, assign path association Z-score data file. Next, assign paths reference data files variables
code: # Path to the input file input_file <- "/Users/leed13/Desktop/GAUSS/GWAS_data/PGC/PGC2/PGC2_final/ilmn1M/pgc2.chr22.ilmn1M.Zonly.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input.data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input.data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2          z #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G -1.4969741 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C  1.8407377 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G  2.1683772 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G -0.0556759 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C  2.9694844 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G -0.8957244 # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file<-"/path/to/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "/path/to/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"path/to/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
text: Lastly, execute dist() function impute association Z-scores missing SNPs genomic region chr22:26M - 27M display results neat table.
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- dist(chr=22, start_bp = 26000001, end_bp = 27000000, wing_size = 500000, study_pop = "EUR",             input_file = input_file,              reference_index_file = reference_index_file,             reference_data_file = reference_data_file,              reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,             af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
code: head(res) %>% kable("html")

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs
code: res.info <- res %>% filter(info>0.6) gwas.sig <- 5*10^-8    ggplot(res.info, aes(x = bp, y = -log10(pval), color = info)) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.8) +   geom_hline(aes(yintercept = -log10(gwas.sig)),               linetype = "dashed",               color = "red",               size = 1.0) +   scale_color_gradient(low = "blue", high = "red") +   labs(title = "Manhattan Plot",        x = "Base Pair Position",        y = "-Log10(p-value)",        color = "Info") +   theme_minimal() #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> â„¹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: vignette provides detailed guide use distmix() function impute association Z-scores unmeasured SNPs multi-ethnic cohorts. â€™ll cover essential arguments needed showcase practical example.

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: distmix() function requires following arguments: chr: Chromosome number. start_bp: Starting base pair position prediction window. end_bp: Ending base pair position prediction window. wing_size: Size area flanking left right prediction window. pop_wgt_df: R data frame containing population IDs wights input_file: File name association Z-score data reference_index_file: File name reference panel index data reference_data_file: File name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: File name reference panel population description data af1_cutff: Cutoff reference allele (a1) frequency

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: ancestry proportion data pop_wgt_df include two columns following names: pop (population abbreviation) wgt (weight proportion). infomormation estimated using afmix() function described . information already available, load data. Letâ€™s load ancestry proportion data generated vignette afmix() function:
code: # Load the ancestry proportion data data("PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop") # data frame name: PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop head(PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop) #>   pop   wgt #> 1 ACB 0.006 #> 2 ASW 0.036 #> 3 BEB 0.005 #> 4 CCE 0.008 #> 5 CCS 0.004 #> 6 CDX 0.018

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: association Z-score data file space-delimited text file including six columns following names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), z (association Z-score). , assign path association Z-score data file:
code: # Define the path to the input file input_file <- "/Users/leed13/Desktop/GAUSS/GWAS_data/PGC/PGC2/PGC2_final/ilmn1M/pgc2.chr22.ilmn1M.Zonly.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input_data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input_data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2          z #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G -1.4969741 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C  1.8407377 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G  2.1683772 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G -0.0556759 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C  2.9694844 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G -0.8957244

text: Next, assign paths reference panel data files:
code: # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file<-"/path/to/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "/path/to/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"path/to/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: now execute distmix() function necessary arguments store results:
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- distmix(chr=22, start_bp = 26000001, end_bp = 26100000, wing_size = 100000,               pop_wgt_df = PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop,               input_file = input_file,                reference_index_file = reference_index_file,               reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,               af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts

title: Imputing Z-scores of unmeasured SNPs from multi-ethnic cohorts
text: , create Manhattan Plot visually represent results:
code: res.info <- res %>% filter(info>0.6) gwas.sig <- 5*10^-8    ggplot(res.info, aes(x = bp, y = -log10(pval), color = info)) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.8) +   geom_hline(aes(yintercept = -log10(gwas.sig)),               linetype = "dashed",               color = "red",               linewidth = 1.0) +   scale_color_gradient(low = "blue", high = "red") +   labs(title = "Manhattan Plot",        x = "Base Pair Position",        y = "-Log10(p-value)",        color = "Info") +   theme_minimal()

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEG
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEG
text: jepeg() function requires seven arguments: study_pop study population group input_file file name GWAS summary statistics data containing rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2 z annotation file name SNP annotation data set reference_index_file file name reference panel index data reference_data_file file name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file file name reference panel population description data af1_cutoff cutoff reference allele, a1, frequency association Z-score data file include six columns following column names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), z (association Z-score). Firstly, assign path association Z-score data file. Next, assign paths reference data files variables
code: # Path to the input file input_file <- "/Users/leed13/Desktop/GAUSS/GWAS_data/PGC/PGC2/PGC2_final/ilmn1M/pgc2.chr22.ilmn1M.Zonly.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input.data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input.data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2          z #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G -1.4969741 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C  1.8407377 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G  2.1683772 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G -0.0556759 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C  2.9694844 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G -0.8957244 # Paths to the annotation file (replace these with your actual paths) annotation_file <- "/path/to/JEPEG_SNP_Annotation.v1.0.txt" # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file<-"/path/to/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "/path/to/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"path/to/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEG
text: Lastly, execute jepeg() function necessary arguments display results neat table.
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- jepeg(study_pop = "GBR",              input_file=input_file,              annotation_file=annotation_file,              reference_index_file = reference_index_file,              reference_data_file = reference_data_file,              reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file)  res <- res[order(res$jepeg_pval),]

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEG
code: head(res) %>% kable("html")

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
code: # Load necessary packages library(gauss) library(tidyverse) library(data.table) library(kableExtra)

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
text: jepegmix() function requires following arguments: pop_wgt_df: R data frame containing population IDs wights input_file: file name GWAS summary statistics data containing rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2 z annotation: file name SNP annotation data set reference_index_file: file name reference panel index data reference_data_file: file name reference panel data reference_pop_desc_file: file name reference panel population description data af1_cutoff: cutoff reference allele, a1, frequency GWAS summary statistics data file include six columns following column names: rsid (SNP ID), chr (chromosome number), bp (base pair position), a1 (reference allele), a2 (alternative allele), z (association Z-score).

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
text: ancestry proportion data pop_wgt_df include two columns following names: pop (population abbreviation) wgt (weight proportion). information estimated using afmix() function described . information already available, load data. Letâ€™s load ancestry proportion data generated vignette afmix() function: Firstly, assign path association Z-score data file. Next, assign paths reference data files variables
code: # Load the ancestry proportion data data("PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop") # data frame name: PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop head(PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop) #>   pop   wgt #> 1 ACB 0.006 #> 2 ASW 0.036 #> 3 BEB 0.005 #> 4 CCE 0.008 #> 5 CCS 0.004 #> 6 CDX 0.018 # Path to the input file input_file <- "/Users/leed13/Desktop/GAUSS/GWAS_data/PGC/PGC2/PGC2_final/ilmn1M/pgc2.chr22.ilmn1M.Zonly.txt"  # Input file should include six columns (rsid, chr, bp, a1, a2, and z) input.data <- fread(input_file, header = TRUE) head(input.data) #>         rsid chr       bp a1 a2          z #> 1: rs1000427  22 36890105  A  G -1.4969741 #> 2: rs1000470  22 24026845  A  C  1.8407377 #> 3: rs1000539  22 20202729  A  G  2.1683772 #> 4:   rs10009  22 22051709  A  G -0.0556759 #> 5: rs1001022  22 26403488  T  C  2.9694844 #> 6: rs1001213  22 34131736  A  G -0.8957244 # Paths to the annotation file (replace these with your actual paths) annotation_file <- "/path/to/JEPEG_SNP_Annotation.v1.0.txt" # Paths to the reference files (replace these with your actual paths) reference_index_file<-"/path/to/33kg_index.gz" reference_data_file <- "/path/to/33kg_geno.gz" reference_pop_desc_file<-"path/to/33kg_pop_desc.txt"

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
text: Lastly, execute jepegmix() function necessary arguments display results neat table.
code: af1_cutoff = 0.001  res <- jepegmix(pop_wgt_df = PGC2_SCZ_ANC_Prop,                 input_file=input_file,                 annotation_file=annotation_file,                 reference_index_file = reference_index_file,                 reference_data_file = reference_data_file,                 reference_pop_desc_file = reference_pop_desc_file,                 af1_cutoff = af1_cutoff)  res <- res[order(res$jepegmix_pval),]

title: Transcriptome wide association study using JEPEGMIX
code: head(res) %>% kable("html")

title: 1000 Genomes Reference Panel (1KG)
text: 1000 Genome population abbreviations. AFR abbreviation African; AMR admixed American; ASN East Asian; EUR European.

title: 33000 Genomes Reference Panel (33KG)
text: 33KG population abbreviations. AFR abbreviation African; AMR admixed American; ASN East Asian; EUR European SAS South Asian.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Donghyung Lee. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lee D (2023). gauss: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics. R package version 1.0, https://github.com/statsleelab/gauss.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gauss: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics},   author = {Donghyung Lee},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 1.0},   url = {https://github.com/statsleelab/gauss}, }

title: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics
text: gauss free open-source R software package, contains functions analyzing summary statistics large-scale genome-wide association studies (GWAS) meta-analyses cohorts diverse ethnic backgrounds, even including family based GWAS, using next generation reference panel consists 32,953 samples 29 populations.

title: Genome Analysis Using Summary Statistics
text: can install development version gauss GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("statsleelab/gauss")
